title: Building Digital Trust: An Empathy-Centred UX Framework For Mental Health Apps
partialText: Designing for mental health means designing for vulnerability. Empathy-Centred UX becomes not a ‚Äúnice to have‚Äù but a fundamental design requirement. Here‚Äôs a practical framework for building trust-first mental health products.

title: Designing For Agentic AI: Practical UX Patterns For Control, Consent, And Accountability
partialText: Autonomy is an output of a technical system. Trustworthiness is an output of a design process. Here are concrete design patterns, operational frameworks, and organizational practices for building agentic systems that are not only powerful but also transparent, controllable, and trustworthy.

title: CSS @scope: An Alternative To Naming Conventions And Heavy Abstractions
partialText: Prescriptive class name conventions are no longer enough to keep CSS maintainable in a world of increasingly complex interfaces. Can the new `@scope` rule finally give developers the confidence to write CSS that can keep up with modern front ends?

title: Combobox vs. Multiselect vs. Listbox: How To Choose The Right One
partialText: Combobox vs. Multi-Select vs. Listbox vs. Dual Listbox? How they are different, what purpose they serve, and how to choose the right one. Brought to you by Design Patterns For AI Interfaces, **friendly video courses on UX** and design patterns by Vitaly.

title: Short Month, Big Ideas (February 2026 Wallpapers Edition)
partialText: Let‚Äôs make the most of the shortest month of the year with a new collection of desktop wallpapers that are sure to bring a smile to your face ‚Äî and maybe spark your creativity, too. All of them were designed with love by the community for the community and can be downloaded for free. Happy February!

title: Practical Use Of AI Coding Tools For The Responsible Developer
partialText: AI coding tools like agents can be valuable allies in everyday development work. They help handle time-consuming grunt work, guide you through large legacy codebases, and offer low-risk ways to implement features in previously unfamiliar programming languages. Here are practical, easy-to-apply techniques to help you use these tools to improve your workflow.

title: Unstacking CSS Stacking Contexts
partialText: In CSS, we can create ‚Äústacking contexts‚Äù where elements are visually placed one on top of the next in a three-dimensional sense that creates the perception of depth. Stacking contexts are incredibly useful, but they‚Äôre also widely misunderstood and often mistakenly created, leading to a slew of layout issues that can be tricky to solve.

title: Beyond Generative: The Rise Of Agentic AI And User-Centric Design
partialText: Developing effective agentic AI requires a new research playbook. When systems plan, decide, and act on our behalf, UX moves beyond usability testing into the realm of trust, consent, and accountability. Victor Yocco outlines the research methods needed to design agentic AI systems responsibly.

title: Rethinking ‚ÄúPixel Perfect‚Äù Web Design
partialText: Amit Sheen takes a hard look at the ‚ÄúPixel Perfect‚Äù legacy concept, explaining why it‚Äôs failing us and redefining what ‚Äúperfection‚Äù actually looks like in a multi-device, fluid world.

title: Smashing Animations Part 8: Theming Animations Using CSS Relative Colour
partialText: CSS relative colour values are now widely supported. In this article, pioneering author and web designer [Andy Clarke](https://stuffandnonsense.co.uk/) shares practical techniques for using them to theme and animate SVG graphics.

title: UX And Product Designer‚Äôs Career Paths In 2026
partialText: How to shape your career path for 2026, with decision trees for designers and a UX skills self-assessment matrix. The only limits for tomorrow are the doubts we have today. Brought to you by Smart Interface Design Patterns, a **friendly video course on UX** and design patterns by Vitaly.

title: Penpot Is Experimenting With MCP Servers For AI-Powered Design Workflows
partialText: [Penpot](https://penpot.app/?utm_source=SmashingMagazine&utm_medium=Article&utm_campaign=MCPserver) is experimenting with MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers, which could lead to designers and developers being able to perform tasks in Penpot using AI that‚Äôs able to understand and interact with Penpot design files. Daniel Schwarz explains how [Penpot MCP](https://github.com/penpot/penpot-mcp) servers work, what they could mean for creating and managing designs in Penpot, and what you can do to help shape their development.

title: Pivoting¬†Your Career Without Starting From Scratch
partialText: Most developers spend their days fixing bugs, shipping features, and jumping into the next sprint without even thinking about it. After a while, you begin to ask yourself, ‚ÄúIs this still what I want to be doing?‚Äù This article looks at how you can move into a new direction in your career without starting from scratch, and how the skills you already use, like problem-solving, communication, and empathy, can open new doors.

title: Countdown To New Adventures (January 2026 Wallpapers Edition)
partialText: Whether 2026 has already begun as you‚Äôre reading this or you‚Äôre still waiting for the big countdown to start, how about some new wallpapers to get your desktop ready for the new year? We‚Äôve got you covered.

title: How To Design For (And With) Deaf People
partialText: Practical UX guidelines to keep in mind for 466 million people who experience hearing loss. More design patterns in Smart Interface Design Patterns, a **friendly video course on UX** and design patterns by Vitaly.

title: Giving Users A Voice Through Virtual Personas
partialText: Turn scattered user research into AI-powered personas that give anyone consolidated multi-perspective feedback from a single question.

title: How To Measure The Impact Of Features
partialText: Meet TARS ‚Äî a simple, repeatable, and meaningful UX metric designed specifically to track the performance of product features. Upcoming part of the Measure UX & Design Impact (use the code üéü IMPACT to save 20% off today).

title: Smashing Animations Part 7: Recreating Toon Text With CSS And SVG
partialText: In this article, pioneering author and web designer [Andy Clarke](https://stuffandnonsense.co.uk) shows his techniques for creating [Toon Text titles](https://stuffandnonsense.co.uk/toon-text/index.html) using modern CSS and SVG.

title: Accessible UX Research, eBook Now Available For Download
partialText: We‚Äôve got exciting news! eBook versions of ‚ÄúAccessible UX Research,‚Äù a new Smashing Book by Michele A. Williams, are now available for download! Which means soon the book will go to the printer. Order the eBook for instant download now or reserve your print copy at the presale price.

title: State, Logic, And Native Power: CSS Wrapped 2025
partialText: CSS Wrapped 2025 is out! We‚Äôre entering a world where CSS can increasingly handle logic, state, and complex interactions once reserved for JavaScript. Here is an unpacking of the standout highlights and how they connect to the bigger evolution of modern CSS.

title: How UX Professionals Can Lead AI Strategy
partialText: Lead your organization‚Äôs AI strategy before someone else defines it for you. A practical framework for UX professionals to shape AI implementation.

title: Beyond The Black Box: Practical XAI For UX Practitioners
partialText: Explainable AI isn‚Äôt just a challenge for data scientists. It‚Äôs also a design challenge and a core pillar of trustworthy, effective AI products. Victor Yocco offers practical guidance and design patterns for building explainability into real products.

title: Masonry: Things You Won‚Äôt Need A Library For Anymore
partialText: CSS Masonry is almost here! Patrick Brosset takes a deep dive into what this long-awaited feature means for web developers and how you could make use of it in your own work.

title: A Sparkle Of December Magic (2025 Wallpapers Edition)
partialText: With December just around the corner, how about some new desktop wallpapers to welcome the last month of the year ‚Äî and the holiday season, if you‚Äôre celebrating? Our latest edition of monthly wallpapers has got you covered. Enjoy!

title: The Accessibility Problem With Authentication Methods Like CAPTCHA
partialText: CAPTCHAs were meant to keep bots out, but too often, they lock people with disabilities out, too. From image classification to click-based tests, many ‚Äúhuman checks‚Äù are anything but inclusive. There‚Äôs no universal solution, but understanding real user needs is where accessibility truly starts.

title: Design System Culture: What It Is And Why It Matters (Excerpt)
partialText: We‚Äôre so happy to announce that ‚ÄúMaturing Design Systems‚Äù‚Äîa Smashing book by Ben Callahan — will soon be joining the Smashing Library! Ben‚Äôs insights and advice are so powerful, we thought you might like to read an excerpt from the book. Subscribe to our Smashing newsletter to be notified when orders are open.

title: Designing For Stress And Emergency
partialText: Practical guidelines on designing time-critical products that prevent errors and improve accuracy. Part of the Measure UX & Design Impact (use the code üéü IMPACT to save 20% off today). With a live UX training starting next week.

title: Keyframes Tokens: Standardizing Animation Across Projects
partialText: Animations can be one of the most joyful parts of building interfaces, but without structure, they can also become one of the biggest sources of frustration. By consolidating and standardizing keyframes, you take something that is usually messy and hard to manage and turn it into a clear, predictable system.

title: From Chaos To Clarity: Simplifying Server Management With AI And Automation
partialText: Server chaos doesn‚Äôt have to be the norm. AI-ready infrastructure and automation can bring clarity, performance, and focus back to your web work.

title: CSS Gamepad API Visual Debugging With CSS Layers
partialText: Debugging controllers can be a real pain. Here‚Äôs a deep dive into how CSS helps clean it up and how to build a reusable visual debugger for your own projects.

title: Older Tech In The Browser Stack
partialText: There are many existing web features and technologies in the wild that you may never touch directly in your day-to-day work. Perhaps you‚Äôre fairly new to web development and are simply unaware of them because you‚Äôre steeped in the abstraction of a specific framework that doesn‚Äôt require you to know it deeply, or even at all. Bryan Rasmussen looks specifically at XPath and demonstrates how it can be used alongside CSS to query elements.

title: Effectively Monitoring Web Performance
partialText: There are lots of tips for [improving your website performance](https://www.debugbear.com/blog/improve-website-performance?utm_campaign=sm-10). But even if you follow all of the advice, are you able to maintain an optimized site? And are you targeting the right pages? Matt Zeunert outlines an effective strategy for web performance optimization and explains the roles that different types of data play in it.

title: Smashing Animations Part 6: Magnificent SVGs¬†With `<use>`¬†And CSS Custom Properties
partialText: SVG is one of those web technologies that‚Äôs both elegant and, at times, infuriating. In this article, pioneering author and web designer Andy Clarke explains his technique for animating SVG elements that are hidden in the Shadow DOM.

title: Six Key Components of UX Strategy
partialText: Let‚Äôs dive into the building blocks of UX strategy and see how it speaks the language of product and business strategy to create user value while achieving company goals. Part of the Measure UX & Design Impact (use the code üéü IMPACT to save 20% off today).

title: How To Leverage Component Variants In Penpot
partialText: With component variants, design systems become more flexible, letting you reuse the same component while adapting its look or state with ease. In this article, Daniel Schwarz demonstrates how design tokens can be leveraged to manage components and their variations using Penpot, the open-source tool built for scalable, consistent design.

title: Fading Light And Falling Leaves (November 2025 Wallpapers Edition)
partialText: The new month is just around the corner, and that means: It‚Äôs time for some new desktop wallpapers! All of them are designed by the community for the community and can be downloaded for free. Enjoy!

title: JavaScript For Everyone: Iterators
partialText: Here is a lesson on Iterators. Iterables implement the iterable iteration interface, and iterators implement the iterator iteration interface. Sounds confusing? Mat breaks it all down in the article.

title: Ambient Animations In Web Design: Practical Applications (Part 2)
partialText: Motion can be tricky: too much distracts, too little feels flat. Ambient animations sit in the middle. They‚Äôre subtle, slow-moving details that add atmosphere without stealing the show. In part two of his series, web design pioneer Andy Clarke shows how ambient animations can add personality to any website design.

title: AI In UX: Achieve More With Less
partialText: A simple but powerful mental model for working with AI: treat it like an enthusiastic intern with no real-world experience. Paul Boag shares lessons learned from real client projects across user research, design, development, and content creation.

title: How To Make Your UX Research Hard To Ignore
partialText: Research isn‚Äôt everything. Facts alone don‚Äôt win arguments, but powerful stories do. Here‚Äôs how to turn your research into narratives that inspire trust and influence decisions.
